Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story: I walked through the door, laptop bag slung over my shoulder, and saw Mia curled up on the couch, scrolling absently through her phone. Her eyes flicked up, and she offered a tired smile. I could tell something was off—her shoulders tense, her responses clipped. I wanted to sit beside her, ask about her day, and just listen, the way she always says helps. But my phone buzzed again: a Slack message from my manager, “Need your estimates for the Q3 roadmap tonight. Can’t finalize without you.” The project planning session had run late, and I still hadn’t finished reviewing the specs. I felt the pressure mounting—Mia needed me to be present, to care, to listen. But my team was counting on me to deliver numbers they could trust, and any delay would ripple through the whole quarter. I stood in the hallway, torn, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which role to step into first.
